Regional Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 39263  
November 2007 
 
 
 
 
Asian Development Outlook 2008
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADO  –  Asian Development Outlook 
  DER  –  Department of External Relations 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  ERMF  –  Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division 
  RETA  –  regional technical assistance 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification  –  General intervention 
Sector  –  Law, economic management and public policy 
Subsector  –  Economic management 
Themes  –  Sustainable economic growth; regional cooperation 
Subthemes  –  Promoting macroeconomic stability; trade and investments

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  its  commitment  to  give  relevant  information  and  analysis,  to  contribute  to  the 
intellectual environment in which policy formulation occurs, and to maintain and enhance its 
reputation as a credible and authoritative source of knowledge about the region, the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  regularly  monitors  and  provides  comprehensive  analysis  on  the 
evolving developments in its developing member countries (DMCs) through the publication of 
the Asian Development Outlook (ADO).1 The ADO has been a flagship publication of ADB since 
1989. Its content informs Management opinion and guides institutional views about prospective 
developments  and  other  important  issues.  The  production  of  the  ADO  has  been  regularly 
supported by technical assistance (TA) funding. The objectives, scope, and activities to be 
covered by the regional TA2 are in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The ADO will be releasing its 20th edition in 2008. Responding to clients’ feedback and 
the rapidly changing marketplace for economic information and analysis, efforts to improve the 
quality of the ADO have intensified in recent years. These efforts have focused on providing 
stronger analytical content and ensuring better cohesion and balance among its parts. If the 
ADO is to remain competitive and relevant as an independent and credible source of knowledge 
and information about the region, continuous work must be done to further improve the quality 
of its analysis. Activities will include the commissioning of relevant applied and policy research 
at  a  country  and  regional  level,  the  development  of  new  sources  of  information,  and 
strengthened peer review. High-quality editing services are crucial to ensure that the ADO’s key 
messages  are  communicated  clearly  and  effectively.  To  increase  the  ADO’s  regional  and 
international reach, the Economics and Research Department (ERD) will continue to collaborate 
with the Department of External Relations (DER). 
 
3.  As the ADO is one of the most frequently downloaded publications from ADB’s website, 
it is directly or indirectly the source of much international and national news commentary that 
features analysis, views, and opinions from ADB.  Thus, a concerted effort, not just to improve 
quality but also to differentiate and disseminate content, is needed to elevate the ADO’s profile.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
4.  The TA will support activities that will contribute to high-quality and comprehensive 
economic analysis of the region and help ensure the usefulness and relevance of ADO to policy 
dialogue and formulation in DMCs. The improved content and structure of ADO 2008 and its 
update  is  expected  to  provide  in-depth,  relevant  and  timely  assessment  of  the  region’s 
economy.  Appendix 2 contains the draft contents pages of ADO 2008 and ADO 2008 Update. 
For its 20th edition, the ADO will feature essays discussing life-cycle issues for workers.  It will 
include  topics  on  the  youth  labor  market,  migration  and  remittances,  workers’  skills  and 
pensions.  
 
                                                 
 
1 The Asian Development Outlook (ADO) is sold externally, and is extensively reviewed and commented on in the 
media. It is the most popular document on the ADB website. 
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 18 July 2007.

2   
5.  The TA will further develop and refine analytical methods to support ADB’s short- and 
medium-term country economic monitoring and reporting. The methods will also strengthen the 
economic underpinnings of country programs and strategies for the DMCs covered. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
6.  The main outputs from the TA will be ADO 2008 and ADO 2008 Update. The TA will 
support  the  following  key  activities:  preparation  of  background  analytical  papers;  further 
development and refinement of analytical methods; drafting of ADO content; economic and copy 
editing; and preparation and layout of materials for publication. The objective of the papers will 
be to provide a solid empirical and analytical foundation for ADO content. The papers will 
supplement the research work of the ADB Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division 
(ERMF) on the selected topics and will contain analysis of issues and policy implications for the 
DMCs covered using a review of existing literature, analyses of survey and macroeconomic 
data and modeling under different scenarios. Activities for the preparation of ADO 2009 will also 
be supported under the TA.  
  
7.  To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency in approach across the different parts 
of the ADO, high-quality editing services are required. Economic and copy editing activities will 
be  provided  by  international consultants  working  under  the  direction  of  the  assistant chief 
economist, ERMF.  
 
8.  Workshops and training directly relevant to the preparation and strengthening of ADO 
content will also be supported by the TA. The focus will be on macroeconomic analysis, growth 
accounting, and economic projections, and effective writing skills, which will target economists 
in regional departments, national officers in resident missions, and, as appropriate, government 
officials and other client groups. The objective of the training is to equip writers with the skills 
and the tools needed to craft high-quality country chapters. The training will also impart skills 
that are of broader relevance for economic and sector work that underpins country strategies.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
9.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $420,000 (Appendix 3). The TA will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
10.  ADB will be the Executing Agency responsible for implementing and monitoring the TA.  
In particular, ERMF will implement the TA in close coordination with regional departments and 
resident missions. The assistant chief economist of ERMF, reporting to the chief economist of 
ERD, will be responsible for implementation. Given the high institutional profile of the ADO, ERD 
will report to the Vice President, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development Group, 
the Managing Director General and the President at critical points in its preparation. 
 
11.  The development of analytical tools and approaches to support high-quality ADO content 
will be a joint effort of ERMF economists, country economists of the regional departments and 
resident missions, national experts, international consultants, and economics editors. The TA 
will finance the procurement of information and knowledge services as may be required to 
support  relevant  and  up-to-date  content.  Procurement  will  be  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). The TA is expected to start in 
December 2007 and to be completed by March 2009.

3
 
12.  An ADO workshop is tentatively scheduled for January 2009 at ADB headquarters. The 
workshop will present and discuss issues and directions on several topics for consideration and 
inclusion in the subsequent year’s ADO. Contents of country chapters and other issues will also 
be discussed during the workshop. 
 
13.  An  estimated  10.5  person-months  (approximately  five  consultants)  of  international 
consultants’ time will be required for economic and technical editing of ADO manuscripts before 
final publication of ADO 2008 and ADO 2008 Update. ADO will also require 4 person-months 
(approximately  two  consultants)  of  international  consultancy  resources  for  preparing 
background  papers.  Another  6  person-months  (approximately  two  consultants)  of  national 
economic consultants’ time will be required to assist in preparing country chapters and data 
sheets. The outline terms of reference for the consultants and resource persons are in Appendix 
4. The consultants will be hired as individuals. Resource persons will also be engaged to 
conduct training workshops and prepare background papers on economic trends and prospects 
of selected DMCs. Consultants and resource persons will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
14.  The major results of ADO 2008 and ADO 2008 Update will be disseminated to the media, 
DMC policy makers, and civil society. Dissemination will be coordinated by DER in cooperation 
with ERMF. Separate launches will be undertaken by resident missions in selected DMCs. Both 
ADO 2008 and ADO 2008 Update will be featured on the ADB website and printed copies will 
be distributed worldwide. In countries where there is limited broadband access, CD-ROMs will 
be made available through the resident missions. The TA will support translation of ADO into 
Chinese and Russian languages to extend its audience in selected DMCs. This will be arranged 
by regional departments in consultation with concerned resident missions and DER. ERMF will 
work with DER to attempt to capture broader and more useful client feedback.  This activity may 
require some limited TA resources. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $420,000 on a grant basis for 
the Asian Development Outlook 2008, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 4 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Economics Consultants (4 person-months, two consultants) 
1.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general macroeconomics and 
good  knowledge  of  the  developing  member  country  (DMC)  economies.  Under  the  direct 
supervision of the TA supervising unit officer, the consultants will 
 
(i)  prepare essays on current issues and country reports as may be assigned; 
(ii)  work with the economics editor to ensure consistency and coherence of the Asian 
Development Outlook (ADO);  
(iii)  perform all other functions and responsibilities as may be assigned by the assistant 
chief economist, Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division (ERMF). 
 
B.  International Economics Editor (6.5 person-months, three consultants) 
2.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF and in consultation 
with other Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff in the Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
involved in preparing and reviewing the country chapters in ADO 2008 and ADO 2008 Update, the 
economics editor will edit the manuscripts for consistency and economic content. The editor will 
assist in preparing the highlights (English version) of the publication. The editor will also ensure that 
all the data in the publication are based on the most recent information available as of the specified 
cut-off date.  
 
3.  In particular, the economics editor will 
 
(i)  edit the ADO for consistency with economic theory as well as empirical evidence; 
(ii)  edit the ADO for internal consistency; 
(iii)  edit the ADO for balanced coverage and degree of detail and precision; 
(iv)  check the report for structure, content, and format to ensure that it conforms to the 
prescribed requirements for the ADO; 
(v)  review the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in the  
  write-up; 
(vi)  confer with ERMF staff regarding gaps in the write-up, important questions, and 
needed revisions; 
(vii)  assist in preparing the publication highlights; 
(viii)  help prepare the key messages and review press releases for the ADO; and 
(ix)  perform all other functions and responsibilities as may be assigned by the assistant 
chief economist, ERMF. 
 
C.  International Copy Editor-cum-Desktop Publishing Specialist (4 person-months, two 
consultants) 
 
4.  Under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist of ERMF, and in consultation 
with the ADO production coordinator, the copy editor will (i) edit ADO 2008 and ADO 2008 Update in 
accordance with ADB’s editorial style; (ii) be responsible for typesetting and proofreading the text, 
tables, and charts from the preliminary draft to the final copy and filming the output before forwarding 
to the external printer; (iii) be responsible for data linking to ensure data integrity and consistency in 
the final manuscript; and (iv) be responsible for converting the desktop file into pdf and html files for 
uploading on the ADB website. The copy editor must have full working knowledge of MS Office (MS 
Word and MS Excel), Adobe Pagemaker and InDesign, and Corel Draw and Illustrator.

Appendix 4  11 
 
5.  In particular, the copy editor-cum-desktop publishing specialist will  
   
(i)  edit the ADO in conformity with ADB’s editorial style and usage; 
(ii)  edit the ADO for consistency and accuracy; 
(iii)  edit the publication summary of the ADO; 
(iv)  supervise the encoding of corrections as well as incorporation of tables, charts,  
and boxes; 
(v)  edit the ADO for balance (in terms of layout); 
(vi)  review the final manuscript for digital printing (via pdf); 
(vii)  prepare the definition, glossary of terms, and list of references; 
(viii)  edit all dissemination materials, including press releases, speeches, questions, and 
answers, key messages and presentation slides;  
(ix)  convert  desktop  files  to  PDF  and  HTML  formats  consistent  with  ADB  website 
guidelines; and 
(x)  perform all other functions and responsibilities as may be assigned by the assistant 
chief economist, ERMF. 
 
D.  Resource Persons 
6.  The  resource  persons  should  have  excellent  working  experience  in  macroeconometric 
modeling and economic projections. In particular, they will 
 
(i)  provide materials for the training workshop; and 
(ii)  conduct a 1-day training workshop on macroeconomics and economic projections at 
ADB headquarters. 
 
7.  Resource persons from selected DMCs will also be engaged to 
 
(i)  prepare a draft background paper on economic trends and prospects of a specific 
DMC, under the direct supervision of the assistant chief economist, ERMF; and 
(ii)  update the ADO data sheet. 
 
E.  National Economics Consultants (6 person-months, two consultants) 
8.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general economics. Under the 
direct supervision of the TA supervising unit officer, the consultants will assist in the economic 
research work of ERD and undertake general economic research.  In particular, they will 
 
(i)  conduct research on issues related to macroeconomic development, growth, trade 
and investment, human capital development, and long-term employment generation 
in the Asia and Pacific region; 
(ii)  support country economic analyses; 
(iii)  contribute to the preparation of ADO 2008 and ADO 2008 Update; 
(iv)  update the ADO data sheet; and 
(v)  undertake  ad  hoc  research  and  other  assignment  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist, ERMF.
